string.text: Standard 9mm pistol cartridge has a bullet with a steel core, pressed into a steel jacket clad with tombac. Used in PM, PB, Fort-12 pistols.

Field tests of the PBM 9x18 cartridge demonstrated its superiority in all combat characteristics over previously proposed variants. The cartridge bullet penetrates standard army body armor at a distance of 30 meters with 100% probability, and a 5mm steel sheet at a distance of 15 meters with 80% probability. None of the bullets developed for the Makarov pistol cartridge showed such high characteristics. Used in PM, PB, Fort-12 pistols.

The 9x19mm "Parabellum" cartridge was developed in 1902 by Georg Luger, who combined the 7.65x22mm cartridge case with a 9mm bullet. The balance of its characteristics in terms of weight, dimensions, and bullet energy allowed it to eventually become the most common pistol cartridge in the world. Used in Walther P99, FN Browning HP, Beretta 92 pistols, as well as in the HK MP5 submachine gun.

The 9x19 +P+ cartridge is a new armor-piercing "Parabellum" of improved modification, developed at the Tula Cartridge Plant. Equipped with a semi-jacketed bullet with a steel core. Used in Walther P99, FN Browning HP, Beretta 92 pistols, as well as in the HK MP5 submachine gun.
Scientists' special round. A modified 9x19mm cartridge that does not harm the victim, but only temporarily paralyzes them.

In 1998, the BP (7N22) cartridge with an armor-piercing bullet was developed and adopted for service, which pierces an armor plate 5mm thick at a distance of 250 meters. The 7N22 bullet uses a pointed core made of high-carbon steel. Used in AKS-74U, AKS-74, AN-94 "Abakan" assault rifles.

The standard 5.45x39mm cartridge belongs to small-caliber cartridges according to Russian classification. The advantage of the cartridge is the terrible wounds that the bullet inflicts when hitting the target. The bullet begins to tumble, tear flesh and gets stuck in bones. Used in AKS-74U, AKS-74, AN-94 "Abakan" assault rifles.

5.56x45-ss190 cartridge - in the 80s in Belgium at the "Fabrique Nationale" firm, a new version of the cartridge with a heavy bullet was developed, designated SS109. Used in Enfield L85A2, LR-300, SIG-550, HK G36, FN F2000 assault rifles.

The 5.56x45mm cartridge (5.56mm NATO, .223 Remington) was developed with the participation of Eugene Stoner, who worked at the "Armalite" firm. This is a variation of the .222 Remington (5.56x42mm) hunting cartridge. In 1964, the US Army officially adopted the .223 Remington cartridge under the designation M193. Used in Enfield L85A2, LR-300, SIG-550, HK G36, FN F2000 assault rifles.

The Mosin 7.62x54R infantry cartridge, born in 1891, underwent structural changes. Armor-piercing. Has a steel core. Designed to engage manpower located behind light armor covers at ranges up to 500 m.

7.62x54 7N14 - Standard army sniper cartridge, has a smaller bullet mass relative to the standard 7.62x54R cartridge, therefore sniper cartridges possess better accuracy. Used in SVD and SVU sniper rifles.
7.62x54 7N1 - Cheap to manufacture modification of the sniper cartridge for SVD, SVU sniper rifles. The cartridge bullet has a lead core.

The 7.62x54mm cartridge (7.62x54, 7.62x54R, 7.62x54R Russian) appeared in 1891. Was adopted as ammunition for the three-line Mosin rifle. Russian rifle cartridge, with a case dimension of 7.62x53.72 mm, total maximum cartridge length of 77.16 mm, bullet diameter of 7.92 mm and energy of 4416 joules. This is one of the oldest rifle cartridges of modern times and, probably, the oldest of the still widely used cartridges. Still used in the army, but not for shooting from the newest automatic rifles, but as ammunition for PK, PKM machine guns.

Sniper cartridge for "Groza", "Val", AK-9, VSK-94 assault rifles and special sniper rifle "Vintorez". Has subsonic flight speed, but due to a heavy bullet of special design pierces most body armor at ranges up to 400 meters.

9x39 SP-6 cartridge is an "assault" one and is intended for engaging targets hiding in vehicles or protected by body armor. The SP-6 cartridge bullet is capable of piercing an 8mm steel sheet at a distance of 100m or hitting a target protected by body armor of protection class 2-3 at 300-400 meters. Used in OTs-14 "Groza", AS "Val", AK-9, VSK-94 assault rifles, as well as in VSS "Vintorez".

The PAB-9 cartridge represents a cheaper version of the SP-6 cartridge and also has a bullet with a steel hardened core. By the way, attempts to replace the SP-6 cartridge with the widely advertised PAB-9 cartridge came down to the supply of several batches of "pabs" to Internal Troops, which are currently prohibited for use (production ceased since 2003). Used in OTs-14 "Groza", AS "Val", AK-9, VSK-94 assault rifles, as well as in VSS "Vintorez". Using this cartridge leads to rapid barrel wear.
Cassettes with ready lethal elements for the gravitational-impulse rifle "Gauss". The source of additional damaging energy is an encapsulated fragment of the "Flash" artifact.

.45 ACP (Automatic Colt Pistol, .45 caliber), is a pistol unitary cartridge developed by John Browning in 1905. It is a popular cartridge for self-defense (especially in the USA). This cartridge is a rimless version of the old revolver cartridge .45 Colt. Used in Colt 1911, SIG P220, USP-45, Desert Eagle pistols and HK UMP-45 SMG.

.45 ACP Federal Hydra-Shok cartridge - The Hydra-Shok bullet from Federal company is known for its high stopping power and remained one of the best in this caliber for many years. Used in Colt 1911, SIG P220, USP-45, Desert Eagle pistols and HK UMP-45 SMG.

Finned bullet, stabilizing in flight, which positively affects accuracy. For TOZ-34, BM-12, Winchester 1300, SPAS 12 shotguns. Increased range and armor-piercing capability - effective at ranges up to 150 meters.

Cartridge with a heavy jacketless bullet. Usually used for hunting large animals, but suitable for other purposes too. Its heavy bullet does not pierce, but practically crushes body armor. Designed for TOZ-34, BM-12, Winchester 1300, SPAS 12 shotguns. Effective at ranges up to 100 meters.

Regular 12-gauge cartridge, loaded with 6mm buckshot. Possesses enormous killing effect at close ranges. Designed for TOZ-34, BM-12, Winchester 1300, SPAS 12 shotguns. Most effective at ranges up to 30 meters.

The first truly mass intermediate (between pistol and rifle) cartridge was created in the USSR in 1943 to ensure troops the ability to effectively conduct automatic fire from light small arms at distances of 200-400 meters. Gained true popularity thanks to the Kalashnikov assault rifle. Used in AK, AKM, AKMN, AK-103, AK-104, AK "Mini-Dragunov", AK "Stormtrooper", RPK, AKS "Scout", AK "Dream" assault rifles, in Simonov carbine and AR-F rifle.

Army ammunition with a bullet with a heat-strengthened core (increased penetration) for AK, AKM, AKMN, AK-103, AK-104, AK "Mini-Dragunov", AK "Stormtrooper", RPK, AKS "Scout", AK "Dream" assault rifles, Simonov carbine and AR-F rifle.
Round with an anti-tank grenade for RPG-7.
Feldsher's special ammo, filled with a mixture of pyroxylin and "Fireball" artifact ground into powder.
NATO standard rifle ammunition. Caliber - 7.62 mm. Simple full metal jacket bullet.
NATO standard rifle ammunition. Caliber - 7.62 mm. Bullet with steel core, improved armor-piercing capability.
Standard 7.92x33 caliber cartridge for German STG-44 "Sturmgewehr" and K-98 rifles.
Armor-piercing 7.92x33 caliber cartridge for German STG-44 "Sturmgewehr" and K-98 rifles.

The .357 HP cartridge is a hollow-point bullet. The projectile's purpose is to slow down impact upon hitting, which reduces its penetrating ability, but at the same time causes greater damage to internal tissues. The high stopping power provided by this cartridge makes it extremely popular among Dutyers, especially for fighting heavier mutants like boars.
Standard grenade for GP-25 "Koster" underbarrel launcher, integrated launcher of "Groza" and RG-6 revolver launcher.

Grenade for GP-25 "Koster" underbarrel launcher, integrated launcher of "Groza" and RG-6 revolver launcher. Before explosion, the grenade jumps to a height of about a meter, which increases its damaging effect.
Defensive hand grenade with a large fragment dispersion radius. Recommended to throw only from cover.
Offensive hand grenade with a small fragment dispersion radius.
RGN hand grenade, short for Ruchnaya Granata Nastupatelnaya (Hand Grenade Offensive), is an offensive Soviet hand grenade.
RGO hand grenade, short for "Ruchnaya Granata Oboronitelnaya" (Hand Grenade Defensive), is a defensive Soviet fragmentation hand grenade.

Homemade flamethrower designed by Freedomer Screw. Fueled by a two-component mixture of colloidal gas "F" and petroleum products. The mixture spontaneously ignites in air, so the design is extremely simple. However, due to the high chemical activity of the mixture, parts made of high-tech anti-corrosion materials obtained in special laboratory conditions are used in the design. Besides, only Screw himself owns the secret of mixture production. For these reasons, the flamethrower did not become a mass product, despite very serious advantages over conventional firearms when meeting some inhabitants of the Zone.

The most ordinary night vision device. Works perfectly in a calmer place. In the Zone, due to the abundance of electromagnetic radiation, the device is strongly susceptible to interference. Noise, defocusing and even image disintegration are possible.

Night vision device assembled on a more advanced element base and equipped with a digital signal filtering system, lighter and more reliable than the standard model. Provides a brighter image with much less noise.

Device allowing detection of objects by their thermal radiation. The thermal imager makes it possible to detect objects in smoke conditions, during intense precipitation and even through non-solid obstacles (for example, dense thickets).
The OTs-04 knife was developed at the Tula Central Design Research Bureau (TsKIB) in the late 80s - early 90s and was intended for special units of the MIA internal troops.
MTech USA Xtreme MX-8054 is a tactical combat knife, specifically designed for tactical purposes and combat scenarios. The blade of this knife was designed with strength and durability in mind.
Rare specimen. A modified version of the AK-12 2012 made to order for a stalker nicknamed "Prince". Has several firing modes: automatic, single and 3-round burst.

A modification of the HK USP Match specially refined for scientists by the personal order of Professor Sakharov, designed for use in the "Specialist-Scientist" kit. The mechanism operation is improved with the help of artifacts. The difference from the standard USP Match is the ability to install a silencer and collimator sights. The pistol comes with an extended magazine for 22 rounds of 9mm caliber.

The AK-12 variant presented to the public in 2016. It differs quite significantly in appearance and design of a number of important units from the previous version of the AK-12 shown in 2015. The design of the assault rifle was revised both to eliminate a number of identified shortcomings and problems, and in the direction of improving manufacturability, taking into account the wishes of the military.

Makhon's personal weapon, made to order for good service. The internal mechanism has been replaced with an improved one, which led to an increase in muzzle velocity and accuracy. Thanks to this, the effective range is increased and the trajectory flatness of heavy subsonic cartridges is improved.

Scientist is another evidence of the professor's care for his wards. A version of Saiga purchased specifically for personnel. Used in "negotiations" with especially dangerous mutants on the transfer of their organs as a gift to science... Experienced hunters look with considerable envy at "scientists" armed with this specimen.
Saiga modified by Mervin's order. A "Picatinny" rail and a massive muzzle brake-compensator are installed, noticeably reducing recoil.

The design of the Kalashnikov AK-74M assault rifle almost completely repeats the AK-74 scheme and has no fundamental differences from the point of view of internal structure. Retaining all the best qualities of Kalashnikov assault rifles, it acquired a number of new ones that significantly improved its combat and operational characteristics. In general, the design of the AK-74M embodied the idea of a "universal" assault rifle replacing four models at once - AK-74, AK-74N, AKS-74 and AKS-74N.
Custom model developed based on the AKM. It is one of the most high-tech weapon samples in the Zone.

Simonov semi-automatic carbine caliber 7.62x39 mm developed on the basis of the Simonov semi-automatic carbine (SKS). Their appearance and overall dimensions are identical. Due to the low price, it is very popular among rookie stalkers.

DVL-10 - a light, compact and silent rifle chambered for new and existing subsonic ammunition was developed for special service and combat tasks requiring special accuracy and range. Equipped with a folding stock unified with other SVL models.

Model developed by Kalashnikov USA based on the Komrad 12 semi-automatic shotgun. The weapon has both dovetail mounts and a "Picatinny" rail for using various types of sights. This model has a new type of trigger mechanism, which allows firing with a cutoff of two rounds.

The AS "Val" special assault rifle was created on the basis of the VSS "Vintorez" silent sniper rifle. It was developed to arm special purpose units of the Soviet army and the Ministry of Internal Affairs. The main purpose of the assault rifle is effective engagement of the enemy using modern means of individual protection, without revealing the shooter's position. Thanks to the integrated silencer and the 9x39 cartridge with a heavy subsonic bullet, the sound of the shot and muzzle flash are minimized.

The AS "Val" special assault rifle was created on the basis of the VSS "Vintorez" silent sniper rifle. It was developed to arm special purpose units of the Soviet army and the Ministry of Internal Affairs. The main purpose of the assault rifle is effective engagement of the enemy using modern means of individual protection, without revealing the shooter's position. Thanks to the integrated silencer and the 9x39 cartridge with a heavy subsonic bullet, the sound of the shot and muzzle flash are minimized.
Developed at the same time as the AS "Val" special assault rifle, the VSS "Vintorez" special sniper rifle is designed for low-noise sniper shooting.

The AKS-74U shortened assault rifle was developed as the main weapon for Spetsnaz forces, Airborne Forces and special units, as well as for crews of armored vehicles who require compact, but at the same time powerful individual automatic weapons. The AKS-74U is much more maneuverable in tight spaces and transport than the full-size AKS-74. However, the short barrel and significantly lower muzzle velocity lead to a short sighting range.

The AKS-74U shortened assault rifle was developed as the main weapon for Spetsnaz forces, Airborne Forces and special units, as well as for crews of armored vehicles who require compact, but at the same time powerful individual automatic weapons. The AKS-74U is much more maneuverable in tight spaces and transport than the full-size AKS-74. However, the short barrel and significantly lower muzzle velocity lead to a short sighting range.

Colt M4A1 - assault rifle (carbine), created in the USA based on the AR-15 platform chambered for 5.56x45 NATO. It was planned for arming crews of combat vehicles and equipment calculations who needed to have weapons of smaller dimensions than standard weapons, but using standard ammunition. However, soon US SOCOM (US Special Operations Command) adopted the M4A1 for all its constituent units. Then followed the full adoption of the M4A1 in the US Army and Marine Corps.

Modernized version of Colt M4A1 Commando (with CQBR) - assault rifle (carbine), created in the USA based on the AR-15 platform chambered for 5.56x45 NATO. It was planned for arming crews of combat vehicles and equipment calculations who needed to have weapons of smaller dimensions than standard weapons, but using standard ammunition. However, soon US SOCOM (US Special Operations Command) adopted the M4A1 for all its constituent units. Then followed the full adoption of the M4A1 in the US Army and Marine Corps.

Glock 17 is an Austrian semi-automatic pistol with a polymer frame, the automatics of which work on the scheme of using recoil with a short barrel stroke, developed by the Austrian firm Glock Ges.m.b.H.

Glock 18 is an Austrian semi-automatic pistol with a polymer frame, the automatics of which work on the scheme of using recoil with a short barrel stroke, developed by the Austrian firm Glock Ges.m.b.H.

The most common pistol in the Zone, a legacy of the Soviet era, the PM is one of the best representatives of the compact self-defense weapon class. It is distinguished by small dimensions, extremely reliable, simple to use and maintain. Among the shortcomings are short range and accuracy of fire, low bullet efficiency, and (in comparison with modern pistols of the same class) rather large mass with insufficient magazine capacity.

Kalashnikov assault rifle caliber 5.45x39 mm, developed in 1970 by designer M. T. Kalashnikov and adopted by the armed forces of the USSR in 1974. It is a further development of the AKM. The development of the AK-74 is associated with the transition to a new low-impulse cartridge 5.45x39 mm.

Originally intended for infantry snipers in every Soviet infantry squad, the SVD was not the weapon of a separate specialized sniper brigade. Being relatively light for a sniper rifle, well balanced and having a semi-automatic firing mode, the SVD shows good but not outstanding results in accuracy. Effective firing range up to 800 meters.

The Dragunov SVDS semi-automatic sniper rifle was developed on the basis of the time-tested SVD rifle for arming snipers of the Airborne Forces and special units needing more compact sniper weapons. Thanks to the use of reliable automatics, the rifle combines good accuracy and grouping of shots, and high practical rate of fire, allowing hitting one target with several consecutive shots or quickly hitting several targets.

Simplicity, durability, low cost and effectiveness of the RPG-7 made it the most popular recoilless anti-tank weapon in the world. Currently it is produced in various modifications by nine countries and is in service with more than 40 countries of the world.

An improved model of the pistol that became a classic of automatic weapons and passed with honor through all armed conflicts of the 20th century. Both in the original and in the modified version, it is still produced by dozens, if not hundreds of manufacturers. The only drawback can be considered the low magazine capacity, but to a certain extent this is compensated by a powerful cartridge.
Unique handmade Colt. The handle is finished with ivory with gilding. The body details are also inlaid with gold. Has increased durability and lethality.

Developed to arm the Swiss Army, the SIG P220 became the basis for a whole family of pistols. These pistols are distinguished by the highest manufacturing quality, without compromise on strength and functionality. The SIG P220 has been adopted by the army and police of Japan, Austria, France, Switzerland and a number of other countries.

An excellent Western-made pistol, distinguished by high reliability, a capacious magazine, good accuracy and, perhaps, the best ergonomics in its class. Once in the Zone, it became one of the most common pistols among both professionals and rookies with money.

Russian single machine gun RPK-16, which was developed to replace the outdated RPK-74. The key features of this weapon sample are quick-change barrels, improved ergonomics, as well as the forend and receiver cover with "Weaver" type rails.

Nikonov assault rifle "Abakan" AN-94 model 1994 based on the Kalashnikov system. The main distinguishing feature of the AN-94 over the AK-74 from the point of view of combat use is the introduction of an additional firing mode in bursts of 2 rounds with a high rate of fire. This firing mode ensures high accuracy and grouping of hits, since the recoil impulse begins to act on the shooter only after both bullets have left the barrel of the weapon.

Model 700 rifles have been manufactured in the USA by Remington since 1962. This is arguably the most widely distributed bolt-action sniper and hunting rifle in the USA. It is a top product of Remington Arms. There are many variants of the rifle for different cartridges, but the standard cartridge is 7.62x51mm NATO. Magazine capacity depends on the caliber and can range from 3 to 20.\nThe design of the 700th was and remains basic for many specialized sniper rifles. The US Marine Corps was among the first to choose the Model 700 as the basis for high-precision sniper weapons. \nM40 rifles used in Vietnam and until the late 70s were created based on the Model 700BDL design. Modern USMC M40A1 rifles are still created based on the same model. When the US Army decided to switch from self-loading semi-automatic sniper rifles to rifles with manual reloading bolt action, the Model 700 was again chosen as the basis for the M24 rifle.

Russian semi-automatic pistol PL-15-01 chambered for 9x19 mm Parabellum. The difference between the pistol and its analogues is its ergonomics and balance, corresponding to current concepts of human biomechanics. The calculation methods of automatics applied during its creation contribute to a large resource of shooting, and in combination with the applied ergonomic solutions, make the pistol comfortable in terms of recoil, muzzle climb after the shot and quick return to the line of sight. All this contributes to a quick second shot and quick transfer of fire, and the ergonomic handle with a large angle of inclination facilitates point shooting.

A pistol developed in the late 1940s - early 1950s by designer I. Y. Stechkin and adopted by the Armed Forces of the USSR in 1951, simultaneously with the Makarov pistol. APS is intended for arming officers taking direct part in combat operations, as well as for soldiers and sergeants of some special units.

MP-133 is a Russian smoothbore shotgun, which is used for various types of hunting, sport shooting, security and self-defense. The shotgun was developed on the basis of the IZh-81 shotgun and has been serially produced by the Izhevsk Mechanical Plant since 2000.

MP-153 is a Russian semi-automatic smoothbore shotgun, popularly called "Murka", which is used for various types of hunting, sport shooting, law enforcement and self-defense, developed and mass-produced at the Izhevsk Mechanical Plant. The shotgun is equipped with an automatic slide stop: after firing the last cartridge, the bolt stops in the rearmost position, which simplifies and speeds up subsequent reloading and signals the shooter about the depletion of ammunition. MP-153 shotguns enjoy quite significant popularity in Russia due to their affordable price, as well as good reliability and survivability. Some disadvantages of the shotgun sometimes include a slightly heavier weight than competitors.

Super-accurate high-tech weapon, known as "Item #62", was developed by designers of secret laboratories inside the Zone. Its principle of operation is based on accelerating the bullet by a system of electromagnets; the bullet is capable of developing super-speeds, which provides tremendous penetrating ability with almost complete absence of recoil. Particles of some artifacts are used to ensure sufficient energy capacity of the accumulators.

Adopted for service in 1967, the PB silent pistol (GRAU index 6P9) was developed on the basis of the Makarov pistol to arm army reconnaissance groups, as well as KGB USSR personnel. The pistol uses an integral silencer that reduces the bullet speed to subsonic.

SR.2 "Veresk" is a Russian submachine gun (manufacturer TsNIITochMash), designed to engage enemy manpower using individual protective equipment in close combat (at a distance of up to 200 m). The main advantage of the SR-2 is high firepower, high accuracy of fire and stopping power of the bullet at close ranges.

Steyr AUG A1 rifle in standard configuration with a non-removable optical 1.5x sight. AUG (Armee Universal Gewehr - army universal rifle) is an Austrian 5.56mm assault rifle of "bullpup" layout, developed in the 1960s by Steyr Mannlicher GmbH&Co KG. In 1978, the AUG was adopted as the standard small arm of the Austrian army under the designation StG 77, where it replaced the 7.62mm StG 58 automatic rifle (licensed FN FAL). In addition, the rifle and its variants were adopted by the armies of Argentina, Australia, Malaysia, New Zealand, Bolivia, Ecuador, Ireland, Luxembourg, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, Pakistan, as well as the US Border Patrol.

Steyr AUG (Armee Universal Gewehr - army universal rifle) is a small arms complex released in 1977 by the Austrian company Steyr-Daimler-Puch. This rifle uses a bullpup layout scheme, in which the magazine and bolt assembly are located behind the fire control handle and trigger. Steyr Mannlicher GmbH & Co KG. The AUG A3 modification is equipped with a "Picatinny" rail instead of the integrated mount for optics of an earlier model, which allows installing almost any optical, night, collimator sights, as well as sighting blocks and conventional mechanical sights on the weapon. In the front part of the receiver, instead of a folding front handle, "Picatinny" guides are also installed, allowing the attachment of various front handles, tactical flashlights, laser designators.

Assault rifle created in the USA based on the M16A2 initially for arming combat vehicle crews and equipment calculations. Despite this, the US Special Operations Command (US SOCOM) adopted this assault rifle as a unified one for all US special operations forces. Currently, the entire US Army is switching to it, since the greater convenience of a shortened carbine in modern conditions, when the majority of the army consists of motorized infantry, combat vehicle crews and auxiliary troops, is a very serious advantage. The main differences between the M4 and the M16A2 are a shorter barrel length and a retractable telescopic stock.
A variant of the AKM with a folding stock. The stock attachment system was changed relative to the AKS (folded down and forward under the receiver).

Development of the SA80 system, which included two weapons - the SA80 IW assault rifle and the SA80 LSW light machine gun, began in the late 1960s when the British Army decided to develop a new rifle to replace the outdated British-made L1 SLR 7.62x51. The standard individual weapon for the British armed forces, the L85 (in the original A1 version), had numerous performance problems. The A2 variant appeared as a result of significant refinement in the early 2000s by Heckler & Koch and remains in service to this day. The L85A2 is extremely reliable in various climatic conditions and is suitable for various operational scenarios. Modern L85A2 rifles are recognized as reliable and accurate, especially when using standard SUSAT optical sights.

Development of the SA80 system, which included two weapons - the SA80 IW assault rifle and the SA80 LSW light machine gun, began in the late 1960s when the British Army decided to develop a new rifle to replace the outdated British-made L1 SLR 7.62x51. The standard individual weapon for the British armed forces, the L85 (in the original A1 version), had numerous performance problems. The A2 variant appeared as a result of significant refinement in the early 2000s by Heckler & Koch and remains in service to this day. The L85A2 is extremely reliable in various climatic conditions and is suitable for various operational scenarios. Modern L85A2 rifles are recognized as reliable and accurate, especially when using standard SUSAT optical sights.

Development of the SA80 system, which included two weapons - the SA80 IW assault rifle and the SA80 LSW light machine gun, began in the late 1960s when the British Army decided to develop a new rifle to replace the outdated British-made L1 SLR 7.62x51. The standard individual weapon for the British armed forces, the L85 (in the original A1 version), had numerous performance problems. The A2 variant appeared as a result of significant refinement in the early 2000s by Heckler & Koch and remains in service to this day. The L85A2 is extremely reliable in various climatic conditions and is suitable for various operational scenarios. Modern L85A2 rifles are recognized as reliable and accurate, especially when using standard SUSAT optical sights.

FN SCAR (Special Operations Forces Combat Assault Rifle) is a weapon system developed by the American division of the Belgian company FN Herstal to participate in the competition for the creation of a new assault rifle for US SOCOM fighters in 2004. In December 2004, this system was declared the winner of the competition, and currently the rifles are entering service with US Rangers. The rifle family consists of two types: SCAR-H and SCAR-L. The SCAR-H (Heavy) rifle is tailored for firing 7.62x51 mm NATO caliber.

Single-shot, muzzle-loaded underbarrel grenade launcher for automatic rifles of Warsaw Pact member countries. The trigger mechanism is double-action, with a manual safety and automatic firing block if installed incorrectly.

Modification of the M203 single-shot grenade launcher with a barrel shortened by three inches and a mount for installation on a "Picatinny" rail. Thanks to the change of mount, this model has found very wide application all over the world. Despite a more modern design, it has mainly the same characteristics as its Soviet counterpart - GP-25.
Skinflint decided to earn some extra money by selling carbines in "his own" body kit. The result turned out to be a good, light and very ergonomic barrel based on the M4.

Representative of a relatively new family of assault rifles. Thanks to high reliability, accuracy of fire and ease of handling, it is one of the best weapon samples of this class. The rifle is equipped with a side-folding skeleton stock and light aluminum bipods on the lower part of the plastic forend. In the Zone it is rarely found and costs a lot of money; usually it is specially ordered for themselves by experienced stalkers.

A compact version of the SIG SG 550 assault rifle, with a 226 mm barrel, designed for special police units. Unlike the SG 550, the return spring is behind the bolt carrier and acts directly on it, not on the gas piston rod. The assault rifle has a modified flash suppressor and can be equipped with "Picatinny" rails for installing additional accessories.

Submachine gun developed by order of the Russian Ministry of Internal Affairs in the early 90s. The design is based, like many other Izhevsk samples, on the units of the Kalashnikov assault rifle, thanks to which many parts are interchangeable with it. In the process of converting to a pistol cartridge, the designers changed the automation scheme for the sake of compactness, and in the PP-19 it works due to the recoil energy of the blowback bolt. The weapon is equipped with a compact and capacious helical magazine, there is also a dovetail mount for installing sights.
Hand-held modification of an army machine gun with belt feed. Despite the high weight and unsatisfactory accuracy of fire, it found itself quite wide application in the Zone.

The HK G28 rifle was developed by Heckler & Koch specifically by order of the Bundeswehr as a support weapon for small infantry units. The G28 is created on the basis of the HK MR308 sports and hunting semi-automatic rifle, which, in turn, is a civilian version of the HK 417 automatic rifle. Despite a number of differences, the HK G28 is 75% interchangeable with the HK 417 in its design. This rifle enables infantry to conduct effective fire at distances inaccessible to standard 5.56 mm assault rifles. \n\nThe Schmidt & Bender "PM II 3-12x50" optical sight was originally created for elite armed forces for rapid target detection and high accuracy. The sight is equipped with an illuminated "Tremor2" reticle, on which there are many marks for calculating accurate shots taking into account distance and wind.

ASh-12 assault rifle is a Russian assault rifle that was developed in 2012. Its creation is associated with the need to modernize standard weapons for the Russian armed forces. Converted by peacekeepers for 7.62x51 caliber.

The PSO-1M (Sniper Optical Sight) is a series of Soviet optical sights produced by the Novosibirsk Instrument-Making Plant. It was developed in 1964 as a standard sight for the SVD rifle. Later it began to be widely used on: 9A-91, AEK-971, AEK-973, AK-74, AKS-74, AKS-74U, AKM, AKMN, AK "hundredth series", AN-94, modifications of AS "Val", RPK-74, SVU and SR-3M. Received recognition for durability, versatility and a very good thoughtful type of reticle with a convenient rangefinder. This specimen is of fixed 4.0x magnification, which makes it suitable mainly for use at long distances. Distributed in the Warsaw Pact countries, uses the dovetail mount.

Collimator sight ELECTRO SIGHT 1x22x33 for quick aiming. Shockproof, fits all types of weapons with a "Picatinny" rail. Selecting the brightness level of the reticle illumination (7 steps) allows using the sight at various levels of illumination.

Detachable optical sight designed for NATO rifles. ACOG stands for Advanced Combat Optical Gunsight and refers to the family of optical sights manufactured by Trijicon. Sights of this type are mounted on a "Picatinny" rail and have tritium illumination. This specimen has a USMC reticle and 3.5x magnification.

EO Tech is a world leader and exclusive manufacturer of holographic sighting systems for small arms. EOTech sights work on the basis of holographic construction of the reticle, due to which they do not have parallax, the reticle is assembled from thousands of small pixels, does not cover the target.

The Kobra sight provides confident aiming in natural lighting conditions (bright sunny day, deep twilight and moonlit night) thanks to the presence of 16 levels of manual brightness adjustment of the aiming mark. The location of the aiming mark and the target in one plane allows aiming with both one and two eyes, which creates an unlimited field of view for the shooter, and conduct effective rapid fire at fast-moving, small-sized and suddenly appearing for a short time targets.

A special version of the PSO-1M sight with a reticle designed specifically to simplify shooting using low-speed, heavy subsonic cartridges of the 9x39 type. The marking of the grid and the special scale of the rangefinder facilitates the calculation of compensating environmental factors. Reticle illumination is provided in low light conditions. This set of properties allowed the use of such sights in special forces. It is also the standard sight on the silent sniper rifle VSS "Vintorez".
Device for silent shooting for FN P90 submachine gun and FN Five-seveN pistol.

Silencer for 9 mm caliber weapons. Archaic in design and at the same time quite effective. Contains inside a tightly packed roll of brass mesh. In the front part of the device there is a set of rubber diaphragms with holes for the passage of the bullet. The silencer is used in close combat against lightly armored opponents and for silent kills.
Device for silent shooting for OTs-33 "Pernach" APS pistol.

Tactical assault rifle silencer (ATG) is designed to reduce the sound and flash of a shot when firing from 5.45 mm Kalashnikov assault rifles AK74, AKS74, AK74M, AK105; 5.56 mm Kalashnikov assault rifles AK101 and AK102, as well as 7.62 mm Kalashnikov assault rifles AK103 and AK104.
Device for silent shooting for Glock, FN FNP, Walther pistols, etc.
Device for noiseless and flameless shooting from SVD.
Device for noiseless and flameless shooting from Kalashnikov assault rifle caliber 7.62 mm. When installing the silencer, shooting is conducted with US cartridges with subsonic bullet speed.
PBS-4. Device for noiseless and flameless shooting from 5.45 mm shortened Kalashnikov assault rifle (AKS-74U).

Tactical silencer-flash suppressor "TGP-A-5.45" for 5.45 mm AK series assault rifles and RPK-74 machine guns. There is no rubber obturator in the silencer design and there is no need to use cartridges with subsonic bullet speed. However, shooting accuracy slightly deteriorates when it is installed.

Advanced silencer for small-caliber rifles, manufactured in the USA. A large number of them for unknown reasons "disappeared" from US Army supply containers. The silencer consists of a high-strength steel body with four expansion chambers, followed by a series of Z-type titanium diaphragms. Effectively reduces muzzle flash and shot sound. Requires minimal maintenance. Silencers of this type are widely used on small-caliber rifles of NATO countries.

Detachable optical sight designed for NATO rifles. ACOG stands for Advanced Combat Optical Gunsight and refers to the family of optical sights manufactured by Trijicon. Sights of this type are mounted on a "Picatinny" rail and have tritium illumination. This specimen has a special "Trijicon" reticle and fixed magnification 2.0x.

The original design of OKP sights makes it possible to conduct aimed fire from unstable positions and in rapidly changing conditions, reduces fatigue, and also, if necessary, allows the use of standard mechanical sights. The main feature of the sight is the reflector mount without a mechanical rim blocking a noticeable part of the firing sectors. Reflector protection in extreme conditions is provided by a thin and durable metal visor that practically does not interfere with shooting.

Possessing the durability that made Aimpoint sights famous all over the world, these small sights are able to withstand extreme conditions, adding only negligible weight to your weapon. Shotguns, rifled weapons of any systems and handguns - these sights can handle everything! Developed for hunters, these sights are the lightest closed-type collimator sights. Lightweight rifled weapons with H-2 installed remain just as light as with a mechanical sight, but allow aiming much faster.

The Kobra sight provides confident aiming in natural lighting conditions (bright sunny day, deep twilight and moonlit night) thanks to the presence of 16 levels of manual brightness adjustment of the aiming mark. The location of the aiming mark and the target in one plane allows aiming with both one and two eyes, which creates an unlimited field of view for the shooter, and conduct effective rapid fire at fast-moving, small-sized and suddenly appearing for a short time targets.

Hybrid optical sight ELCAN SpecterDR 1-4x DFOV14-T1 is a unique development of a Canadian company with the ability to switch between 1x and 4x magnification with one movement. The DFOV14-T1 reticle with ballistic points applied taking into account the flight path of a 5.56 NATO (.223 Rem) caliber bullet, guaranteeing high accuracy at any distance. All this makes the sight suitable for both driven hunting and classic hunting with approach or from an ambush. The design features of ELCAN SpecterDR guarantee constant eye relief regardless of the selected magnification, ensuring comfortable aiming in conditions where it is necessary to quickly switch to targets located at different distances from you. \n\nThe optimal design transmits the maximum amount of light, which in combination with proprietary multi-layer anti-reflective coating applied to lenses made of high-quality glass, guarantees bright, contrast, with excellent color reproduction without distortion over the entire field of view. The body of the ELCAN SpecterDR sight is made of durable and at the same time light material resistant to large mechanical loads. Complete water resistance makes it possible to use the sight even in the most adverse conditions. The included special anti-glare nozzle on the lens will completely eliminate the possibility of unmasking during hunting in sunny weather. (The sight has backup sights mounted on top).

The PSO-1M (Sniper Optical Sight) is a series of Soviet optical sights produced by the Novosibirsk Instrument-Making Plant. It was developed in 1964 as a standard sight for the SVD rifle. Later it began to be widely used on Kalashnikov assault rifles, light machine guns, special rifles and carbines. Received recognition for durability, versatility and a very good thoughtful type of reticle with a convenient rangefinder. This specimen is of fixed 4.0x magnification, which makes it suitable mainly for use at long distances. Distributed in the Warsaw Pact countries, uses the dovetail mount.

The original design of OKP sights makes it possible to conduct aimed fire from unstable positions and in rapidly changing conditions, reduces fatigue, and also, if necessary, allows the use of standard mechanical sights. The main feature of the sight is the reflector mount without a mechanical rim blocking a noticeable part of the firing sectors. Reflector protection in extreme conditions is provided by a thin and durable metal visor that practically does not interfere with shooting.

The purpose of "Hyperon" sniper pancratic sights is reconnaissance of targets and conducting aimed fire from sniper rifles. They provide automatic input of the aiming angle in the process of measuring the distance to the target. Using the 1P59 "Hyperon" pancratic sight when firing from a sniper rifle allows increasing the effectiveness of firing from SVD compared to the standard PSO-1 sight by 1.3...2 times (depending on the range and size of the target) due to greater magnification, use of a more accurate rangefinder, combining operations of measuring the distance to the target and inputting aiming angles, as well as placing the scale of aiming angles input in the sight's field of view.

MEPRO M21 - developed in close cooperation with Israeli special forces. The sight works in daylight from a light-gathering element, and at night from tritium. Switching between the two power elements is instantaneous and automatic. Works in any weather and temperature conditions. The 30 mm diameter lens provides a larger field of view and quick target acquisition. The viewing sector is unlimited, can be used with both eyes open.

The sight has a wide field of view and single magnification, which allows conducting a quick overview of the terrain simultaneously with the naked eye and through the sight without losing visibility of the target in conditions of dynamic combat. In order to minimize weight and dimensions, the 1P76 sight uses an erecting system on a Pechan prism and an adjustment mechanism with lens movement. The reticle is illuminated by a tritium light element.

Collimator sight Kobra EKP-8-18 of open type with an electronic circuit for controlling brightness and switching types of aiming marks. The sight is designed for installation on weapons with a "Picatinny" or "Weaver" rail.
Shot sound moderator from Hexagon company for SKS.
Closed collimator sight from the Swedish company Aimpoint AB. Designed for conducting accurate fire at short and medium distances.
FALKE "LE" collimator sight. Thanks to its design, it allows using it on a wide range of weapons. Compatible with night vision devices.
Prismatic 2x sight "Compact Prism Scope" manufactured by Monstrum Tactical.
The world's first wide field battle sight. Radically new design for professional and civilian MSR/AR shooters, BRAVO4 provides industry-leading field of view 42% wider than existing battle sights.
Prismatic 3x sight "Trihawk Prism Scope 3x30" manufactured by SwampFox.
Muzzle brake-compensator Rotor 43 is designed for installation on SVD-S 7.62x54. Positioned specifically as a muzzle brake, but at the same time also reduces the sound of the shot.
Standard Salvo 12 silencer for 12 gauge weapons manufactured by SilencerCo.

The AAC 762 SDN-6 silencer is designed for use with 7.62x51 NATO caliber cartridges, but can also be used with 300 AAC, 6.8 SPC, 6.5, and 5.56mm NATO cartridges. Can only be installed on compatible muzzle devices with "51T" type thread.
Tactical silencer-flash suppressor developed specifically for use on the SVDS rifle. Can also be used on some PKM/PKP series machine guns.
Lightweight silencer manufactured by SilencerCo for 9 mm caliber.
Device for silent shooting for 9x18mm pistols. Can be used with the PMM pistol or any other favorite one having a barrel with suitable threading.
Shot sound moderator from Hexagon company for 5.45x39 and 7.62x39 calibers.
Shot sound moderator from Hexagon company, designed for carbines and shotguns of 12 caliber.
Silent shooting device model BLACK BOX .45 manufactured by Advanced Armament Corp. Suitable for most 9mm and .45ACP pistols, the barrel of which is equipped with special threading.
Quick-detach silencer designed for installation on Remington Model 700
Silent shooting device for 9x21 mm caliber. Requires special threading on the weapon barrel for installation.
Homemade silent shooting device made by Forester for his own modification of the Mauser 98k sniper rifle. A special adapter must be installed on the rifle barrel for attachment.
Laser Designator for Lebedev Pistol PL-15
Laser target designator allows conducting aimed fire from almost any position.\n
Silent shooting device for Lebedev PL-15 pistol.
Silent shooting device for APS pistol, improved with a tactical kit.
Silent shooting device for SR2M submachine gun.
30 mm light grenade launcher, developed by designers of the Monolith faction, based on the special silent grenade launcher 6G17 "Kanaryeka".
Silent shooting device for Steyr Aug carbine.
Reliable universal silencer from Advanced Armament Corp for AR-15 carbines.
40 mm grenade launcher developed by Belgian company FN Herstal for FN SCAR assault rifle.
The M320 underbarrel grenade launcher was created by Heckler & Koch in 2008 to replace the M203 underbarrel grenade launcher.
Installed on the HK "Prolonged" flash suppressor installed on G28.
Timberwolf - silencer for .338 caliber sniper rifles. Manufactured by Canadian company PGW Defense.
Silent shooting device for .45 caliber pistols.

When an inexpensive short-range weapon is needed that will be effective and deadly, many rookie stalkers resort to sawing off the stock and barrels of the easily acquired TOZ-66 double-barreled shotgun - this makes the gun light and maneuverable at the expense of accuracy and firing range.\n \n

Being a powerful weapon that every stalker can afford, the TOZ-66 is reliable and effective. However, this hunting rifle is quite large and bulky, so many stalkers prefer to spend their hard-earned money on a modern pistol.\n \n

Assault rifle-grenade launcher complex, 70% unified with assault rifles of the AKS-74U type (main differences - caliber 9x39 mm, "bullpup" layout scheme and wider opportunities for modernization). Developed for arming rapid reaction units. Highly valued by military and stalkers for the ability to reliably hit an enemy protected by body armor or located in cover. Can be assembled in 4 different configurations, depending on the combat mission. The common version of the assault rifle in the Zone is equipped with a GP-25 underbarrel grenade launcher.

OTs-14 "Groza", which lay for some time in the "Fruit Punch" anomaly. Acquired an absolutely incredible and inexplicable property, namely: now this barrel uses "Slug" as ammo. Truly, the Zone sometimes works miracles not only with a person, but also with objects. These miracles and metamorphoses are beyond understanding.

OTs-14 "Groza", which lay for some time in the "Electra" anomaly. Acquired an absolutely incredible and inexplicable property, namely: now this barrel uses ammo from the "Gauss" rifle. Truly, the Zone sometimes works miracles not only with a person, but also with objects. These miracles and metamorphoses are beyond understanding.

Developed by the American company Magnum Research, the Desert Eagle uses a gas-operated mechanism usually used in rifles. This allows the pistol to use bullets of a much larger caliber than in traditional semi-automatic pistols. The disadvantages of this weapon include considerable size and heavy weight.

Fort-17 is a Ukrainian semi-automatic pistol chambered for 9x18 mm PM. Developed in the spring of 2004, produced by NPO "Fort". "Fort-17" is a modification of the "Fort-12" pistol with a polymer frame made of reinforced fiberglass impact-resistant polyamide, a detachable grip backstrap (allowing fitting to the shooter's hand) and a "Picatinny" mount under the pistol barrel. The use of polymers made it possible to reduce weight, increase manufacturability and reduce the cost of pistol production.

A modified model of the pistol from the first half of the 20th century - just as reliable, accurate and powerful as the original sample. This model gained a reputation as one of the best pistols of the 20th century and is very popular among stalkers.

The M320 underbarrel grenade launcher was created to replace the M203 underbarrel grenade launcher. M320 was produced based on Heckler Koch AG36, but they are not completely identical. Production started in November 2008.

MP5A3 is an MP5 variant equipped with a retractable metal stock. This submachine gun deservedly enjoys immense popularity due to reliability, ease of handling and high accuracy of fire. Adopted by army and police units of many countries, it appeared on the black market, eventually reaching the Zone.

A revolver-type grenade launcher used to increase infantry firepower in urban combat conditions. Used in some local conflicts, for example, the war in Chechnya. The front-loading drum chambers are formed by six rifled barrels identical to those used in underbarrel grenade launchers. Designed to fight the enemy in shelters and conduct area fire. Also useful when attacking well-guarded objects or in battle with particularly tenacious creatures.

The TOZ-34 over-and-under hunting shotgun was developed by talented designers of the Tula Arms Plant N.I. Korovyakov and V.P. Ochnev in 1965. Affordable price, great stopping power and the ability to fire from both barrels simultaneously quickly made it popular among rookies on the outskirts of the Zone. Especially effective against mutants due to high stopping power.
Carbine converted for firing non-lethal ammunition of 7.62 mm caliber.
Has increased lethality and durability, installed sight and silencer.

Smoothbore shotgun, which was developed in 1978 when the Olin/Winchester corporation sold the rights to manufacture weapons under the Winchester brand to the US Repeating Arms Company. The new shotgun was based on the design of the Winchester 1200 model, produced by Olin/Winchester corporation from 1964 to 1980.

FAMAS stands for Fusil d'Assaut de la Manufacture d'Armes de St-Etienne (Assault Rifle of the St-Etienne Arms Factory). Development of this rifle began in 1967 by French weapon designer Paul Tellie. The new rifle was intended to replace the outdated self-loading rifles MAS Mle.49/56, MAT-49 submachine guns and MAC Mle.1929 light machine guns. The first FAMAS prototype was built in 1971, and in 1972 the French military began testing this rifle. Meanwhile, as an interim solution, France adopted the Swiss-designed SIG SG-540 5.56 mm assault rifle. FAMAS was adopted by the French in 1978 and has since become the standard rifle of the French army, known among French soldiers as "Le Clairon" (bugle). With an additional handle for better stability when firing. \n\nAfter adoption by the French army, FAMAS F1 replaced the outdated MAS 49/56 rifle and MAT-49 submachine gun. About 400,000 FAMAS F1 assault rifles were produced by MAS. Although the FAMAS F1 rifle was quite powerful, it had many problems.

Raging Bull is a revolver created by the Brazilian firearms manufacturing company Taurus International. This weapon is positioned as a hunting one, thanks to its caliber. Fits quite tightly in the hand, has a red rubber insert reducing recoil, which allows the shooter to feel more comfortable.

MP-155 is a Russian semi-automatic smoothbore shotgun, developed and mass-produced at the Izhevsk Mechanical Plant. The shotgun is equipped with reliable automatics with a wedge locking bolt. MP-155 shotguns enjoy quite significant popularity due to affordable price, as well as good reliability and survivability.

The embodiment of new trends in Western automatic weapons: the operating principle of the automatic system is based not on a semi-free shutter, but on a short stroke of the gas piston. It should be noted that these changes have proven beneficial: this assault rifle is a first-class example of modern weapons - lightweight, reliable and ergonomic

Belgian submachine gun developed in the mid-90s by FN Herstal. Created primarily for tankers and crews of other combat vehicles. Has a progressive and comfortable ergonomic design and is equipped with a built-in laser target designator. Specially for P90, a 5.7x28 mm SS190 type cartridge was developed, possessing high penetrating power and low tendency to ricochets.

RAPTR automatic shotgun with magazine feed, born in the Zone and created taking into account the specifics of this dangerous part of the world. High rate of fire, large magazine and unsurpassed ergonomics make it an ideal weapon.
Mossberg 590A1 is a popular choice among shooters who require a reliable shotgun for tactical and defensive purposes.
Parabellum Pistol or Parabellum-Pistol (Pistol Parabellum), widely known as simply Luger or Luger P08, is a semi-automatic pistol with recoil operation and a toggle-lock action.

Adapting the gas system of Soviet SVT-40 rifles, Nazi Germany, based on the earlier Gewehr 41 model, developed the Gewehr 43 semi-automatic rifle. In 1944 it was renamed Karabiner 43. Being equipped with a ZF-4 optical sight, it was quite an effective sniper rifle for that time.

Designed for rapid delivery of explosive firepower, the M32 can hold several 40mm grenades in a rotating cylinder, which allows producing a quick sequence of shots without the need for manual reloading. Its light and portable design makes it suitable for various tactical operations, including infantry support, crowd control and perimeter defense.

MP9 is a submachine gun created by Brugger + Thomet AG based on the TMP. Main differences: presence of a stock folding to the right and a "Picatinny" rail for installing additional sights. Is in service with special forces units, and is also widely used by special services and companies responsible for the safety of top state officials, high-ranking figures.

HK416 A5 is a further step in the development of the HK416 assault rifle in 5.56x45 mm NATO caliber. The main changes compared to previous generations are - an improved gas regulator that no longer requires additional tools, an updated receiver with double-sided controls, improved compatibility with magazines from different manufacturers and many other changes aimed at improving the ergonomics and reliability of the weapon. This version is equipped with a 60-round drum magazine from Magpul.

MDR automatic rifle developed and built in bullpup configuration by the American company Desert Tech LLC. The basic design of the rifle is designed for a relatively powerful rifle cartridge 7.62x51 NATO and is intended for arming police and army special forces units.

MDR automatic rifle developed and built in bullpup configuration by the American company Desert Tech LLC. The basic design of the rifle is designed for a relatively powerful rifle cartridge 7.62x51 NATO and is intended for arming police and army special forces units. This version is executed in FDE coloring and equipped with a 50-round drum magazine from Magpul.

KRISS Vector submachine gun - a compact weapon system for combat in confined spaces, will be an ideal choice for law enforcement officers and armed forces. Low location of the barrel bore, as well as the Super V recoil compensation system, allow obtaining the best result both when firing in automatic mode and with rapid single fire.

SV-98M is a modernization of the SV-98 rifle, during which the body and barrel were completely replaced, due to which the weight was reduced, ergonomics improved, firing range and accuracy increased, and a new sight with greater magnification was installed.
"Vintorez-M" is an improved version of the "Vintorez" sniper rifle adopted by the Russian army back in 1987. The feature of the updated weapon is improved characteristics in accuracy and grouping.

The Mosin rifle, also called simply "Mosinka" or three-line rifle, is the most famous rifle in the post-Soviet space. Adopted for service back in 1891, it continued to be mass-used until the end of the 50s of the XX century.

SR-3 "Vikhr" is a compact Russian assault rifle developed on the basis of the AS "Val" silent assault rifle. SR-3M is distinguished by the possibility of using a silencer, metal magazines for 30 rounds, installation of optical and night sights, a frame stock folding to the left (borrowed from AS "Val"), a flag safety catch made like SVD type, and a new forend with a folding additional handle.
FAL - NATO firearm manufactured in Belgium by Fabrique Nationale de Herstal. One of the most recognized and widespread automatic rifles

Feldsher remade it, replacing the barrel and bolt mechanism with more durable ones made of metal-ceramic. Although this noticeably increased the weight. Special cartridges filled with a mixture of pyroxylin and "Fireball" artifact ground into powder are used as ammunition.
A single-barrel revolver-type shotgun. It is one of the most original weapons developed by Russian gunsmiths at the end of the last century.
